source.raw_text:
A Seated Curl-Bar Press (often called a Seated EZ-Bar Curl to Press) primarily targets the Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, and Forearms, with secondary involvement from Anterior Deltoids, combining elbow flexion (curling) with shoulder flexion/pressing. The movement pattern involves curling the bar up (like a standard bicep curl) and then continuing the upward motion to press it overhead, engaging shoulders at the top before slowly reversing the motion back down. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked: 

• Primary Movers (Biceps & Forearms): 

    • Biceps Brachii: The main muscle on the front of your upper arm, responsible for flexing the elbow. 
    • Brachialis: A deeper elbow flexor that pushes the biceps up, adding arm size. 
    • Brachioradialis: A forearm muscle that assists with elbow flexion, especially in the lower part of the curl. 

• Secondary/Stabilizers: 

    • Anterior Deltoids (Front Shoulders): Engaged as the movement transitions from a curl to an overhead press. 
    • Core/Glutes: Braced to stabilize the torso and prevent swinging. [2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

This video demonstrates the proper form for a seated curl-bar press: 
Movement Pattern: 

1. Starting Position: Sit on a bench, feet flat, holding the EZ-bar with an underhand grip (palms up or angled). 
2. The Curl Phase: Flex at the elbows, bringing the bar up towards your chest/nipple line, squeezing the biceps. 
3. The Press Phase (Transition): Continue the motion, pressing the bar overhead until your arms are extended. 
4. The Descent (Reverse): Control the weight as you lower it back to shoulder height (reverse of the press) and then continue lowering to the starting curl position, maintaining tension. 
5. Controlled Repetition: Perform in a smooth, controlled manner, avoiding momentum and focusing on the eccentric (lowering) phase for better muscle engagement. [2, 5, 6]  

You can also watch this video to learn how to perform the standard seated barbell curl: 
Key Considerations: 

• Grip: The EZ-bar's angles reduce wrist and elbow strain compared to a straight bar. 
• Focus: It combines bicep isolation with shoulder engagement, making it efficient but requiring control to avoid using momentum. 
• Weight: Start light to master the combined movement before increasing load. [1, 2, 10]
